September 1st. 1959

div1.p: I suppose the classic way to induce your sympathetic attention to this letter and its contents --especially if the writer has become over the years somewhat of a stranger -- is t to say it is from one who was and still is, an intense admirer of your "Song of Hugh Gl,ass," "The Song of Three Friends," and other narratives of the pioneerinvg West, and who expressed this admirat on with enthusiasm in the columns of the Old Boston Transcript.
I hope the reference is sufficient warrant for you to listen to, and comply if you will, to the request in this letter.

May I preface the request with a recollection of a similar poetic activity I engaged in nearly half a century ago? A poetict activity, as far as I know, which had not been attempted before that accomplishment nor since?

The first occasion was when I asked a group of American poets to write original poems to honor the Centenary o of the birth of Robert Browning. These were published in the pages of the Boston TTranscript and were highly commended. One of these s so-called "made to order poems," was George Sterling's "ode" to Browning, and later was awarded the second prize in the Lyric Year Contest. The second occasion were the poems written at my request, to celebrate the victory of the Allied Arms at the conclusion of World War One. These were published in book form with an Introduction by Theodore Roosevelt - the last piece fof writing he did.

Now coming up is the Centenary of the Civil War. The prose-writers are producing books dealing with every phase of the Conflict in commemoration of this anniversary event. What all these studies and re-interpretations will lack is the imagination and visional re-creation of the poet.

I am intensely anxious, and fantastically ambitious, that the poets should have a collective voice in this historic anniversary. I am, therefore, asking a group of our leading poets to write original poems so that poetry might have an impressive and conspicuous participation in this event. Will you join the chorus and write such a poem to add the lustre of your name and tehe radiant evocation of your imagination to this group?

All the poests shall be free to deal with any phase of the crisis, the conflict itself as enacted through battles, or influenced by personalities; free to use any pattern of verse (which of course, goes without saying) and with no restrictions as o to the length of the verse.

My plan for the publication of the poems is thi this: We are combing the 1959 and 1960 Anthologies in one volume and will add these Centenary poems a section of the book which is to be schueduled for publication in October, 1960. I am asking that the manuscripts of the poems be in my hands by February First, 1960
We cannot hope to pay what your poem will be worth but will make a token payment. If you will consent to make the effort and lwill let me knoqw at your earliest convenience I will be grateflul.
